titleStmt.title: Here endeth a lytyll tratyse named Le assemble de dyeus
Assembly of gods.

editionStmt.edition: This text is an enriched version of the TCP digital transcription A06541 of text S109242 in the English Short Title Catalog (STC 17007). Textual changes and metadata enrichments aim at making the text more computationally tractable, easier to read, and suitable for network-based collaborative curation by amateur and professional end users from many walks of life. The text has been tokenized and linguistically annotated with MorphAdorner. The annotation includes standard spellings that support the display of a text in a standardized format that preserves archaic forms ('loveth', 'seekest'). Textual changes aim at restoring the text the author or stationer meant to publish.

respStmt.resp: This text has not been fully proofread

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 115 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 46 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

publicationStmt.pubPlace: Evanston,IL, Notre Dame, IN, St. Louis, MO

availability.p: This keyboarded and encoded edition of the work described above is co-owned by the institutions providing financial support to the Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership. This Phase I text is available for reuse, according to the terms of Creative Commons 0 1.0 Universal . The text can be copied, modified, distributed and performed, even for commercial purposes, all without asking permission.

titleStmt.title: Here endeth a lytyll tratyse named Le assemble de dyeus
Assembly of gods.
titleStmt.author: Lydgate, John, 1370?-1451?, attributed name.

notesStmt.note: An edition of: The assembly of the gods.
Title from colophon, which ends with Wynkyn de Worde's device.
The first leaf has woodcuts on recto and verso, both printed sideways.
Caption title, a2r: Here foloweth the interpretacyon of the names of goddys and goddesses as is rehersed in this treatyse folowyng as poetes wryte.
a3 text begins: Whan Phebus in the crabbe had nere his cours ronne.
Reproduction of the original in the British Library.
